doc.title: F4Q25 Beat But FY26 Guide Disappoints
doc.source_uri: 2025-08-28/Nutanix Inc F4Q25 Beat But FY26 Guide DisappointsNutanix Inc F4Q25 Beat But FY26 Guide Disappoints_2025-08-28

passages.text: Despite the solid Q with strong new logo performance across all customer tiers, FY26 guidance disappointed on uncertain macro (i.e. US Fed), lower expected growth rate in ACV renewals, expected y/y decline in average- contract duration, and select opex headwinds.

NTNX highlighted significant wins in the Q, such as its first wins for its cloud platform supporting Dell PowerFlex - this included two deals with North American based Global 2000 companies (a financial services provider and medical equipment provider). We view the early PowerFlex wins as positive, given the Dell PowerFlex solution is more tailored for the top end of the customer pyramid. Notably, these wins also came in ahead of internal expectations, given these customer types tend to be fairly conservative. These wins allow NTNX the opportunity to expand within the customer over time. Management expects to get more wins over the year as well. In regards to the previously announced PSTG partnership, NTNX continues to expect the offering to be generally available by end of CY25. PSTG has a broader footprint than PowerFlex, and we expect this to begin contributing to revenue in late FY26. We expect to continue to see new logo win momentum in FY26 with VMW share gains continuing to be a multi- year theme (management views they are in the second inning at this point) - NTNX has added 2,700 customers over the last year, but there are still \(\sim 200k\) customers out there for VMW.

NTNX had a good FQ4 in US Fed, although longer deal cycles remain in the vertical. US Fed has been \(\sim 10\%\) or less of annual revenue. Macro remains dynamic and management highlighted this was factored into the guide. Management highlighted the increase in the number of \(\) 1M+\(land and expand ACV transactions in FY25, although noted they are still a minority of the overall land and expand ACV. NTNX noted that due to the average deal size of new logos increasing over the last few years, this can potentially be a headwind for the growth rate of expansion within those customers (given the deal size is now larger than it has historically been).

Delayed hiring apon- recurring partner payments are expected to be opex headwinds in FY26, although we view both as more of a timing issue vs a structural change in opex. Despite the wins in the Q, NRT at the end of Q4 was \(108\%\) , down from \(110\%\) the prior three Qs.

The numbers: 4FQ25 revenue of \(\) 653M\(came in ahead of Street estimate of\) \ \(643M\) and GM of \(88.3\%\) was above Street's \(87.8\%\) estimate (we do not see considerably more room for GM expansion). EPS of \(\) 0.37\(was five cents higher than the Street. ARR and net new ARR came in below Street.
Please see analyst certifications and important disclosures beginning on page 4. Completed: 28- Aug- 25, 04:18 GMT Released: 28- Aug- 25, 04:23 GMT Restricted - External

Source: IDC Link to Barclays Live for interactive charting

Positives: Early PowerFlex wins a positive, especially with customers in the higher end of the pyramid. We expect to NTNX to continue to see wins moving through FY26 and for the PSTG partnership to be additive. Management still views VMW share gain opportunity as in early innings, and a multi-year opp. Gross margin of \(88.3\%\) remains best in class.

Concerns: FY26 guide disappointed, as well as commentary around ACV/ARR. Opex headwinds expected in FY26, although we do not view this a structural issue but merely timing. NRR dipped in the Q and depressed commentary around ARR and ACV likely pressuring the stock after hours. However, management did highlight that having their external storage offering does give NTNX some pricing advantages, and they have seen an increase in ASPs for their deals in terms of total size of the deals.

Estimates and rating: We maintain our OW rating on the new logo momentum and multi- year theme of VMW share gains. However, we lower our PT to \(\) 82\$ from \(\) 94\(, given FY26 guidance and compressed ACV/ARR commentary. Our PT goes to\) \ \(82\) based on a 7.5x revenue multiple on FY27E revenue of \(\) 3.3\(Bn. Our prior PT of\) \ \(94\) was based on 9x our prior FY26E revenue of \(\) 2.9\(Bn.

Overweight - The stock is expected to outperform the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a 12- month investment horizon.
Equal Weight - The stock is expected to perform in line with the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a 12- month investment horizon.
Underweight - The stock is expected to underperform the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a 12- month investment horizon.
Positive - industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are improving.
Neutral - industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are steady, neither improving nor deteriorating.
Negative - industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are deteriorating.

Source: Bloomberg, Barclays Research
\*This is the closing price referenced in the publication, which may not be the last available closing price at the time of publication.
Historical stock prices and price targets may have been adjusted for stock splits and dividends.
Valuation Methodology: Our price target of \(\) 82\$ applies an EV/sales multiple of 7.5x to our FY27 revenue estimate of \(\) 3.3\$ . Our target multiple is in line with software trading comps.

Risks which May Impede the Achievement of the Barclays Research Valuation and Price Target: Public cloud vendors represent the biggest threat to NTNX. Exposure to hardware partners with conflicting interests and split loyalty. Audit committee investigation. Hybrid and multi- cloud momentum could subside; NTNX is still indexed to on- prem workloads. Continued business transition creates execution risk. Recession and macro headwinds risk.

Sustainable Investing Related Research: There is currently no globally accepted framework or definition (legal, regulatory or otherwise) of, nor market consensus as to what constitutes a 'sustainable', 'ESG', 'green', 'climate-friendly' or an equivalent company, investment, strategy or consideration or what precise attributes are required to be eligible to be categorised by such terms. This means there are different ways to evaluate a company or an investment and so different values may be placed on certain sustainability credentials as well as adverse ESG- related impacts of companies and ESG controversies. The evolving nature of sustainable investing considerations, models and methodologies means it can be challenging to definitively and universally classify a company or investment under a sustainable investing label and there may be areas where such companies and investments could improve or where adverse ESG- related impacts or ESG controversies exist. The evolving nature of sustainable finance related regulations and the development of jurisdiction- specific regulatory criteria also means that there is likely to be a degree of divergence as to the interpretation of such terms in the market. We expect industry guidance, market practice, and regulations in this field to continue to evolve.
